WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Yeah, they're interns. July is tough. But they get faster, and they can take the complex patients sooner, by month 2 they can do a moderate degree of resus on their own. Our auditioning med students see 2-3 patients at a time, and the resident helps offload some of the work so the students can spend more time in the room and seeing interesting stuff.   In the same way that you expect your team to do their part of the list, we expect everyone in the ED will be pushing themselves to carry their weight. The difference is when we're inpatient, we get assigned half the list, whereas in the ED the expectation is that you'll be self-governing. No one is assigning you patients, but we notice when you've spent a loving hour carrying one patient and you're not jumping to pick up another while the senior is carrying the rest of the board.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: With a K of 2.3 in a vomiting patient it will take 6-8 hours to run the K in IVPB, and potentially another 2 hours if we need to replete Mg. Then they need repeat labs. \xe2\x80\x9cTitrating the treatment to response and trending labs on stable patient\xe2\x80\x9d is definitionally medicine. If we had an obs unit I'd do it myself, but we don't.   Also, these days I'm seeing half my patients in the waiting room. Our volume overwhelms our supply of rooms. If someone's workup is done in the waiting room they can certainly be admitted from there.   I would actually love an ED obs unit though, because there really are a lot of patients who don't need a full admission! They need ten hours of treatment, or some extra time for case management to arrange home oxygen, or some other thing that is not worth a second H and P. The hospitals I work in though are community sites; they'll never build out the infrastructure for that nor will they staff it. So here we are.

WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Yep. The ED is a consult service for everyone else in the system. WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: All my overuse injuries are from road running, and since I was primarily a trail runner before I did not appreciate how fricking terrible roads are on my joints.
